text:
(1)
Doyers Street, west from the Bowery.
1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

(2)
The same, at an earlier date. Note entrance to the Chinese Theatre, at Nos. 5-7 on the left of view. Buildings on the right (Nos. 6, 8, and 10), are 3-story frame houses.
About 1890.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

In the older view, note at No. 8, the Chatham Club; the cabaret where Irving Berlin, the famous songwriter first started. Facing same is the old Chinese Theatre, that has now become the Chinatown Mission. This, in conjunction with the Arcade (wooden structure at the head of the bend) played a major role in the intermeicine strife that habitually flares up in this locality and thereby caused this turn to be known as the Bloody Angle. No. 3 has been stated as the site of the home of Anthony H. Doyer in 1809, the individual whose name is perpetuated here. Around the bend on the right, Scotchy Lavelle maintained a dive at No. 14. Occupying the Bowery corners were similar enterprises, Barney Flynn's and Callahan's.

(1)
Doyers Street, west from but not including the Bowery. Nos. 12 and 14 are 2-story frame houses.
April 21, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

April 21, 1928.

(3)

Division Street, south side, east from but not including Catherine Street, to, but not including Market Street. No 7 Division Street, east of the S.E. corner of Division and Catherine Streets, is a 4-story frame house. The view shows the Second Ave., elevated overhead on Division Street.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies, Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

(1)
Bowery, west side, north from Doyers Street. At this point overhead the Second and Third Ave., Elevated lines converge.
October 8, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, slightly northward.
October 8, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
The Bowery, at the N.W. corner of Doyers (left) Street as viewed westward under the Third Ave. Elevated Structure. 1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad, A.R.P.S.
title: Manhattan: Bowery - Doyers Street

text:

Bowery and Doyers St., Manhattan

Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer

[Note: negative at Museum of the City of New York]
Code II A-3
April 24, 1936

NYPL Neg # 341
title: Manhattan: Bowery - Doyers Street

text:
No's. 9 & 8 Chatham Square, west side, between Doyers and Mott Sts., showing the lower stories only. The Grand Windsor Hotel is No. 9. Overshadowing this area is the elevated structure of the 2nd & 3rd Avenue Lines.

About 1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad A.R.P.S.
title: Manhattan: Chatham Square - [Between Doyers and Mott Streets.]

text:
Doyers Street, at the Bowery, showing several Oriental characters at the N. W. corner of same. This is the entrance to section of New York's Chinatown, known as the "Bloody Angle!" About 1936.
Gift Of Dr. Michael Wishengrad A.R.P.S.
